topComments.author: @burkov
topComments.authorProfile: Book: https://t.co/tSS6Pctj6r App: https://t.co/APb9rPQQ9b PhD in AI, author of ğŸ“– The Hundred-Page Language Models Book & The Hundred-Page Machine Learning Book
topComments.originalQuote: Claude has a serious problem that turns users off: its extreme wokeness, which they call "safety." Among the frontier models, Claude is the most "lobotomized" (aka "aligned") model, which rejects answering innocent questions. Other chatbots might also refuse to answer some questions, but Claude is the only one to lecture the user on moral high grounds. It doesn't just say, like a machine should, "Sorry, but I cannot answer this question." It explains that it has moral principles and that this kind of question is against them. These kinds of statements from a tin can make users feel like they are being taken for criminals, bigots, or something like that. It's a huge turn-off. And now they've just added this infamous 8-level safety system and threaten to sanction paying users if they misbehave. Because Anthropic didn't manage to attract casual users, while professional users always migrate to whoever is stronger or cheaper, it will lose professional users to either Google or DeepSeek or whoever comes next. Claude and OpenAI are too expensive (Claude Sonnet costs $15 per 1M output tokens, while o1 costs $60; compare this to ~$3-$8 for DeepSeek R1 or $0.40 for the recently released Gemini 2.0 Flash from Google). While OpenAI still has some tiny edge with o3-mini, Anthropic has nothing but arrogance.
